The Szekelys, or Szeklers, were, I imagine, the same people, called in Latin Siculi, in Hungarian Szekely, and by the neighboring nations Secui, who were counted by the Romans among the free Dacians, that is, Dacians who had remained free, and had not been subjected to the Roman rule. They have preserved their liberty, and maintained their independence, even to the present day, governing themselves after their ancient manner, by a prince, and a council of nobles, and enjoying all the privileges of nobility. They are a very proud people, and in their own opinion, much superior to all the other inhabitants of the country, whom they look upon as their inferiors. They are a very warlike people, and have always been so, and have in all times, been the defenders of the country against the Turks. They are well skilled in arms, and well acquainted with the use of them, and are, in short, a very brave people. They are also a very hospitable people, and very courteous to strangers, and are famous for their feasts, and their love of pleasure. They are also a very superstitious people, and have many strange customs, and opinions, which are not to be found among any other people. They have a great veneration for their ancestors, and for the memory of Attila, and the Huns, and have many traditions, and stories, concerning them, which they relate with great pleasure, and satisfaction. en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

en_results_raw: way, and he mumbled something under his breath, as if to prevent his wife from speaking. I was about to ask further questions, when the door opened and a tall, thin man with a sallow complexion and sunken eyes entered the room. He was dressed in a long, black coat with a cape, and a wide-brimmed hat covered his head. He bowed low and introduced himself as the Count's servant, come to escort me to the coach. I was surprised, as I had not expected such a grand send-off, and I felt a shiver run down my spine as I followed him out of the house and into the bright sunlight. The coach was waiting in the courtyard, its horses snorting and pawing the ground impatiently. The servant opened the door and helped me in, and as I settled into my seat, he bowed again and closed the door behind me. I was alone in the coach, and as it began to move, I felt a sense of excitement and trepidation. Where was I being taken, and what lay ahead? I looked out of the window, but all I could see was the dusty road unwinding into the distance, with the occasional tree or bush flashing by. The coach was well-sprung, and I felt myself being lulled into a state of drowsiness, but I was determined to stay awake and alert, for I had a feeling that something important was about to happen.

This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

es_first_half: 4 de mayo. Averigüé que mi posadero había recibido una carta del conde, ordenándole que asegurara el mejor lugar del coche para mí; pero al inquirir acerca de los detalles, se mostró un tanto reticente y pretendió no poder entender mi alemán. Esto no podía ser cierto, porque hasta esos momentos lo había entendido perfectamente; por lo menos respondía a mis preguntas exactamente como si las entendiera. Él y su mujer, la anciana que me había recibido, se miraron con temor. Él murmuró que
es_second_half: el dinero le había sido enviado en una carta, y que era todo lo que sabía. Cuando le pregunté si conocía al Conde Drácula y si podía decirme algo de su castillo, tanto él como su mujer se persignaron, y diciendo que no sabían nada de nada, se negaron simplemente a decir nada más. Era ya tan cerca a la hora de la partida que no tuve tiempo de preguntarle a nadie más, pero todo me parecía muy misterioso y de ninguna manera tranquilizante.
es_results: no sabía nada, pero que el conde le había dado instrucciones precisas para que me tratara con la mayor cortesía. La anciana, que parecía más asustada que él, me rogó que no me inquietara por nada, que todo se arreglaría, y me ofreció una taza de té. Me senté a la mesa y comencé a beber el té, pero no podía evitar sentir que algo extraño estaba sucediendo. De repente, el posadero salió de la habitación y regresó con un hombre alto y delgado,
es_results_raw: no sabía nada, pero que el conde le había dado instrucciones precisas para que me tratara con la mayor cortesía. La anciana, que parecía más asustada que él, me rogó que no me inquietara por nada, que todo se arreglaría, y me ofreció una taza de té. Me senté a la mesa y comencé a beber el té, pero no podía evitar sentir que algo extraño estaba sucediendo. De repente, el posadero salió de la habitación y regresó con un hombre alto y delgado, de ojos oscuros y penetrantes. Se acercó a mí y se presentó como el secretario del conde. Me dijo que el conde deseaba verme en su castillo y que había enviado un coche para llevarme allí. Me sentí un poco inquieto, pero no tenía razones para negarme. Así que me levanté y seguí al secretario hasta el coche. Mientras nos alejábamos del posadero, no pude evitar sentir que estaba siendo llevado a un destino desconocido, y que mi vida estaba a punto de cambiar para siempre.

en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? The inscription on the stone read: "In loving memory of John and Emily, who were taken from us too soon. May their love and legacy live on forever." The old man's eyes seemed to cloud over as he gazed at the stone, and for a moment, I thought I saw a glimmer of tears in his eyes. "You see, my friend," he said, his voice low and husky, "this is what I mean. This is the kind of thing that brings comfort to those who are grieving. Not some false and empty words, but a genuine tribute to the memory of those who have passed on." He paused, collecting his thoughts before continuing. "I have lived in this village all my life, and I have seen many people come and go. But I have never seen anyone who was more loved and respected than John and Emily. They were good people, kind and gentle, and their passing was a tragedy that was felt by everyone in the community." The old man's words were like a punch to the gut, they hit me with such force and emotion that I felt like I had been winded. I looked around at the other graves, each one with its own story to tell, its own memories and emotions. And I realized that this was what it was all about, this was what made life worth living. Not the big things, not the grand gestures, but the small, quiet moments, the memories that we hold dear, the love that we share with others.

I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

es_first_half: No pareció transcurrir mucho rato, sino más bien que fue muy, muy terrible, hasta que pude recobrar nuevamente la conciencia. En algún lugar cercano, una campana doblaba; todos los perros de la vecindad estaban aullando, y en nuestros arbustos, aparentemente muy cercanos, cantaba un ruiseñor. Yo estaba aturdida y embotada de dolor, terror y debilidad, pero el sonido del ruiseñor pareció la voz de mi madre muerta que regresaba para consolarme. Los ruidos parece que también despertaron a las sirvientas, pues pude oír sus pisadas descalzas corriendo fuera de mi puerta. Las llamé y entraron, y cuando vieron lo que había sucedido, y qué era lo que descansaba sobre mí en la cama, dieron gritos. El viento irrumpió a través de la rota ventana y la puerta se cerró de golpe. Levantaron el cuerpo
es_second_half: de mi amada madre y la acostaron, cubriéndola con una sábana, sobre la cama, después de que yo me hube levantado. Estaban tan asustadas y nerviosas que les ordené fueran al comedor a tomar cada una un vaso de vino. La puerta se abrió de golpe unos instantes y luego se cerró otra vez. Las sirvientas gritaron horrorizadas, y luego se fueron en grupo compacto al comedor, y yo puse las flores que había tenido alrededor de mi cuello sobre el pecho de mi querida madre. Cuando ya estaban allí recordé lo que me había dicho el doctor van Helsing, pero no quise retirarlas, y, además, alguna de las sirvientas podría sentarse conmigo ahora. The mourners assembled in the parlour, and the coffin was borne out to the hearse, which was drawn up in front of the house. The procession moved slowly through the streets, the passers-by stopping to gaze after it, and the blinds being drawn down in the windows of the houses as it passed. The burial-ground was some distance from the town, and the drive was a long and melancholy one. The rain fell gently on our faces as we stood around the open grave, and the wind sighed through the trees as the minister performed the last rites. It was a solemn and impressive scene, and one that I shall never forget.

en_first_half: “I hope,” said Van Helsing, “that when you are sending the child home you will caution its parents to keep strict watch over it. These fancies to stray are most
en_second_half: dangerous; and if the child were to remain out another night, it would probably be fatal. But in any case I suppose you will not let it away for some days?”
en_results: dangerous, and if the child were to be found dead, with the marks of the vampire's teeth in its throat, they would be sure to hang the first person against whom
en_results_raw: dangerous, and if the child were to be found dead, with the marks of the vampire's teeth in its throat, they would be sure to hang the first person against whom their suspicions might turn. And so, to save themselves from the hangman's noose, they would be sure to make away with the real culprit. But, I suppose, it is hardly likely that such a thing would happen in this enlightened age. Still, I think it is well to be prepared for any eventuality, and to take all the precautions that we can. Now, I must be off, for I have a long journey before me, and I must not delay. I will write to you from Whitby, and tell you all that I can about the place, and the people, and what I have discovered. And I will also tell you what I think of the child, and what I think is best to be done. Until then, farewell, and may God be with you.

It's like a constant hum in the background, a reminder of all the things I need to do. I know I'll be exhausted tomorrow if I don't get some rest, but my body seems to be refusing to cooperate. I'll just have to try and hope that somehow, someway, I'll be able to get through the day ahead.

en_second_half: and I could not believe that she was dead. The lips were red, nay redder than before; and on the cheeks was a delicate bloom.
en_results: and yet there was a something in her eyes, a something so unnatural and so unutterably dreadful, that it made my very blood run
en_results_raw: and yet there was a something in her eyes, a something so unnatural and so unutterably dreadful, that it made my very blood run cold as I gazed upon her. Her lips were as red as ever, but they seemed to be curled into a faint, mirthless smile, and her skin was as smooth and unblemished as alabaster, but it was deathly pale. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I looked at her, and I knew that I was in the presence of something that was not of this world.

Mientras hablaba, el doctor Seward se sentó en su asiento, con los ojos fijos en mí, y su expresión era de la más intensa atensión. De vez en cuando, asentía con la cabeza, como si estuviera siguiendo un hilo de ideas que yo no podía ver. Cuando hube terminado, el doctor Seward se levantó y se acercó a mí, con una sonrisa de satisfacción. "Gracias, señorita", me dijo. "Ha sido de gran ayuda. Ahora, si me disculpa, debo escuchar la grabación para asegurarme de que todo esté claro." Y, con eso, se sentó de nuevo en su asiento y comenzó a escuchar la grabación, con la misma atensión con que me había escuchado a mí.

en_first_half: “No, sir. But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that. It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.” I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself. If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved. At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional
en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

en_results_raw: Club, where the houses are numbered, I found the house with the stone front and the bow window, and the high steps leading up to the door. I felt a sense of excitement and trepidation as I stood before the house, wondering if I was finally closing in on the Count's lair. I took a deep breath, and began to ascend the steps, my eyes fixed on the door. As I reached the top, I noticed that the door was slightly ajar, and I could hear a faint noise coming from within. I pushed the door open slowly, and stepped inside, my heart pounding in my chest. The interior of the house was dimly lit, and I had to wait for a moment for my eyes to adjust to the darkness. As I looked around, I saw that I was in a narrow hallway, with a staircase leading up to the floors above. The air was thick with dust, and cobwebs hung from the ceiling. I could hear the sound of scurrying feet coming from the room to my left, and I turned to face it. Suddenly, a figure emerged from the room, and I saw that it was a young woman, with a look of terror in her eyes. She saw me, and let out a scream, and I realized that I had stumbled into something much bigger than I had ever imagined. I tried to speak to her, to calm her down, but she was beyond reason. She turned and ran back into the room, and I followed her, my heart racing with anticipation. As I entered the room, I saw that it was some sort of laboratory, with all sorts of strange equipment and contraptions. And then I saw him, the Count, standing in the corner of the room, a look of fury in his eyes. He was holding a small box in his hand, and I knew that it was the earth-box, the source of all the terror that had been unleashed on the city. I knew that I had to act fast, to stop him before it was too late. But as I approached him, I felt a strange sensation, a feeling of weakness and dizziness. I tried to speak, to warn him, but my words were slurred and indistinct. And then everything went black.
vi_first_half: — Không, thưa ngài, nhưng mà tìm cũng dễ thôi! Ngôi nhà cao, mặt tiền xây bằng đá, cửa sổ thấp, có bậc thềm bên ngoài. Sở dĩ tôi còn nhớ cái bậc thềm này là vì phải đưa các thùng hàng lên cùng với ba thằng nhà quê nữa, bọn chúng xin giúp tôi để mong kiếm được vài xu. Lão già đã cho chúng mấy đồng shilling. Thấy bở, chúng định đòi thêm mấy đồng, nhưng đời nào lão chịu. Suýt nữa thì mấy thằng đã bị lão đá văng xuống chân cầu thang nếu như chúng không kịp bỏ chạy cùng vài câu chửi thề tục tĩu. Nghĩ như thế cũng là đủ để tìm ra ngôi nhà, tôi bèn trả tiền cho Bloxam và tìm đường tới Piccadilly. Điều tôi vừa được biết khiến tôi không khỏi bối rối: lão bá tước có thể tự tay nâng các thùng gỗ chứa đầy đất! Mỗi phút trôi qua lúc này đối với tôi đều rất đáng quý. es_first_half: –No, señor. Pero no tendrá dificultades en encontrarla. Es un edificio alto, con una fachada de piedra y un escudo de armas y unas escaleras bastante altas que llegan hasta la puerta de entrada. Recuerdo esas escaleras debido a que tuve que subir por ellas con las cajas, junto con tres muchachos que se acercaron para ganarse unos peniques. El viejo les dio chelines y, como vieron que les había dado mucho, quisieron más todavía, pero el anciano agarró a uno de ellos por el hombro y poco faltó para que lo echara por las escaleras; entonces, todos ellos se fueron, insultándolo. Pensaba que con esos informes no tendría dificultades en encontrar la casa, de modo que después de pagarle a mi informante, me dirigí hacia Piccadilly. Había adquirido una nueva y dolorosa experiencia. El conde podía por lo visto manejar las cajas solo. De ser así, el tiempo resultaba precioso, puesto que ya que había llevado a cabo ciertas distribuciones, podría llevar a cabo el resto de su trabajo, escogiendo el tiempo oportuno para ello, pasando completamente inadvertido. En Piccadilly Circus me
es_second_half: apeé y me dirigí caminando hacia el oeste; después de pasar el junior Constitutional, llegué ante la casa que me había sido descrita y me satisfizo la idea de que se trataba del siguiente refugio que había escogido Drácula. La casa parecía haber estado desocupada durante mucho tiempo. Las ventanas estaban llenas de polvo y las persianas estaban levantadas. Toda la estructura estaba ennegrecida por el tiempo, y de las partes metálicas la pintura había desaparecido. Era evidente que en el balcón superior había habido un anuncio durante cierto tiempo, que había sido retirado bruscamente, de tal modo que todavía quedaban los soportes verticales. Detrás de la barandilla del balcón vi que sobresalían varias tablas sueltas, cuyos bordes parecían blancos. Hubiera dado mucho por poder ver intacto el anuncio, puesto que quizá me hubiera dado alguna indicación en cuanto a la identidad de su propietario. Recordaba mi experiencia sobre la investigación y la compra de la casa de Carfax y no podía dejar de pensar que si podía encontrar al antiguo propietario era posible que descubriera algún medio para entrar en la casa.

Ev, uzun süredir içinde oturulmuyormuş gibi görünüyordu. Pencereleri toz kaplıydı ve kepenkleri açıktı. Tüm çerçeveler zamanla kararmış, demirin üstündeki boyanın çoğu çıkmıştı. Son zamanlara kadar balkonun önünde büyük ilan tabelası olduğu belliydi, ama hoyratça oradan sökülmüştü, tabelayı tutan direkler hâlâ orada duruyordu. Balkon demirlerinin arkasında, cilasız kenarları beyaz görünen bazı gevşek tahtalar gördüm. As I watch her, I feel a sense of calm wash over me, and my own eyelids begin to feel heavy. I lean back in my chair, trying not to make a sound, and let my gaze drift around the room. The shadows on the walls seem to grow longer and darker, like skeletal fingers reaching out to snatch at the last remnants of light. But even they seem peaceful, as though they too are sleeping. en_first_half: “Dr. Seward, you have been very considerate towards me. Believe me that I am very, very grateful to you!” I thought it well to leave him in this mood, and so I came away.
en_second_half: There is certainly something to ponder over in this man’s state. Several points seem to make what the American interviewer calls “a story,” if one could only get them in proper order. Here they are:—
en_results: As I walked back to my lodgings, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief wash over me. The weight of the past few days had been bearing down on me, and Dr. Seward's words had been a balm to my frazzled
en_results_raw: As I walked back to my lodgings, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief wash over me. The weight of the past few days had been bearing down on me, and Dr. Seward's words had been a balm to my frazzled nerves. I knew that I still had a long way to go, but for the first time in what felt like an eternity, I felt a glimmer of hope. Perhaps, just perhaps, I would be able to find some measure of peace and move forward from the darkness that had consumed me for so long. The thought was a fragile one, and I knew that it could be shattered at any moment, but for now, I held onto it tightly, letting its warmth spread through me like a gentle flame.

en_first_half: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through
en_second_half: the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”

vi_first_half: Ngoài ra, sự thành công của phi vụ còn phụ thuộc vào sự cả tin của các nhân viên cảnh sát khu vực. Nhưng anh bạn Jonathan thân mến ạ, đôi khi anh vẫn có thể dùng móc mở khóa hàng trăm ngôi nhà ở Luân Đôn hoặc ở bất kỳ đâu trên thế giới này mà không sao, miễn là anh tạo ra một hoàn cảnh thích hợp và làm đúng lúc. Tôi có thể kể cho mọi người nghe một câu chuyện mà tôi đã từng đọc. Chuyện là thế này: Có một quý ngài sở hữu một biệt thự tuyệt đẹp ở Luân Đôn. Mùa hè năm đó, do có việc phải đi Thụy Sĩ trong một thời gian khá lâu, khoảng dăm bảy tháng gì đó, ông đã chủ quan khóa cửa nhà trước khi lên đường và chẳng cần nhờ ai trông nom hết. Kết quả là sau khi ông đi được một thời gian ngắn, có kẻ trộm đã đập vỡ kính một ô cửa sổ nhìn ra vườn rồi đột nhập vào trong. Vào nhà rồi, hắn bèn mở tất cả các ô cửa sổ ở mặt tiền của ngôi nhà và đàng hoàng mở cửa chính đi ra ngoài ngay trước mắt đám cảnh sát. Sau đó, hắn công khai rao bán sạch mọi đồ đạc trong nhà bằng một tấm biển quảng cáo to tướng dán trên tường ngoài cổng, hắn đã nhờ một đại diện bán đấu
vi_second_half: giá tới bán tất cả đồ đạc của quý ngài đang ở Thụy Sĩ kia. Thế rồi chính ngôi nhà cũng bị hắn bán tống cho một chủ thầu xây dựng vì hắn đã tìm được giấy tờ sở hữu cất trong nhà. Tay chủ thầu đã bàn với hắn phá bỏ ngôi nhà vào một ngày cụ thể để cất lên một tòa nhà mới. Cảnh sát và chính quyền thành phố cứ tưởng hắn là chủ nhân thật sự của ngôi biệt thự nên đã tạo điều kiện thuận lợi cho hợp đồng xây dựng trao tay này. Chỉ buồn cho người chủ thật sự của ngôi nhà, từ Thụy Sĩ về, trước mắt ông chỉ còn là một cái hố vĩ đại thế chỗ cho ngôi nhà thân quen của ông. Nhưng biết làm sao được, mọi việc đều diễn ra hợp lệ, đúng nguyên tắc mua bán và xây dựng mà thành phố đã quy định. Có lẽ công việc của chúng ta cũng nên tuân theo các nguyên tắc tương tự. Không nên đến Piccadilly quá sớm để tránh sự soi mói của cảnh sát, chỉ có như vậy họ mới không tình cờ để ý thấy sự xuất hiện của chúng ta là không bình thường. Sớm lắm thì cũng chỉ được phép bắt đầu từ mười giờ trở đi, vì khi đó, thể nào người qua lại cũng nghĩ chúng ta chính là chủ nhân thực sự của ngôi nhà.
vi_results: giá để thanh lý tài sản. Mọi người trong xóm đều thấy rõ ràng việc làm của hắn, nhưng không ai có thể nghi ngờ rằng hắn là một tên trộm. Bởi vì hắn đã làm mọi việc một cách công khai và có vẻ như là chủ nhân của ngôi nhà. Hắn đã bán được tất cả mọi thứ, từ chiếc giường ngủ, chiếc tủ quần áo, cho đến chiếc bàn ghế, chiếc đèn bàn... Tất cả mọi thứ đều được bán với giá rất rẻ, và người mua cũng không cần phải nghi ngờ gì cả. Cuối cùng, hắn đã bán cả ngôi nhà với giá rất cao cho một người đàn ông già. Người đàn ông già này đã trả tiền và nhận nhà, nhưng khi ông ta vào nhà để dọn dẹp và chuẩn bị chuyển vào ở, thì ông ta mới phát hiện ra rằng ngôi nhà không phải là của hắn. Ông ta đã bị lừa đảo và mất sạch tiền. Câu chuyện này đã được đăng tải trên báo chí và gây ra sự phẫn nộ trong công chúng. Nó cho thấy rằng, trong xã hội hiện đại, có rất nhiều người có thể làm việc sai trái và lừa đảo người khác một cách rất tinh vi. Vì vậy, chúng ta cần phải cẩn thận và tỉnh táo khi đối mặt với những tình huống không rõ ràng. Chúng ta cần phải kiểm tra và xác minh mọi

es_first_half: –Entonces -me miró fijamente, al tiempo que continuaba -, todo lo que estará en duda es la conciencia y la opinión de la policía en cuanto a si es el propietario quien recurrió al cerrajero y la opinión de la policía en cuanto a si el artesano está trabajando o no de acuerdo con las leyes. Su policía debe estar compuesta de hombres cuidadosos e inteligentes, extraordinariamente inteligentes para leer el corazón humano, si es que han de estar seguros de lo que deben hacer. No, no, amigo Jonathan, puede usted ir a abrir las cerraduras de un centenar de casas vacías en su Londres o en cualquier ciudad del mundo, y si lo hace de tal modo que parezca correcto, nadie intervendrá en absoluto. He leído algo sobre un caballero que tenía una hermosa casa en Londres y cuando fue a pasar los meses del verano en Suiza, dejando su casa cerrada, un delincuente rompió una de las ventanas de la parte posterior y entró. Tanto la policía como el resto de las autoridades inglesas lo ayudaron todo lo que pudieron. Polisleriniz, kendilerini böyle bir konuyla sıkıntıya soktuklarına göre, insan yüreğini okuma konusunda istekli ve akıllı - ah, hem de nasıl akıllı - olmalılar. Hayır, hayır, dostum Jonathan, Londranızda ya da dünyanın herhangi bir başka şehrinde yüz boş evin bile kilidini sökseniz ve bu işi olması gerektiği gibi yaparsanız kimse işinize karışmaz. Londranızda çok güzel bir evi olan ve yaz için birkaç aylığına İsviçre’ye gidip evini kapattığında bir hırsızın arka pencereyi kırıp içeri girdiği bir beyefendinin öyküsünü okumuştum. en_results_raw: of a sudden, as if moved by a single impulse, bowed our heads and closed our eyes. The old man's hands, which we still held, trembled slightly, and his voice, low and solemn, began to speak. The words were indistinguishable at first, but as he continued, they grew louder and more distinct, until we could make out a low, chanting prayer, the words of which were unfamiliar to us, but the tone and the emotion behind them were unmistakable. As he prayed, the room seemed to grow quieter, the shadows deepening and the air thickening, as if the very atmosphere was being charged with an almost palpable sense of reverence and awe. And when he finally fell silent, the stillness was oppressive, punctuated only by the sound of our own ragged breathing, and the faint, mournful sigh of the wind outside.

en_first_half: Whilst he was speaking we were startled by a knock at the hall door, the double postman’s knock of the telegraph boy. We all moved out to the hall with one impulse, and Van Helsing, holding up
en_second_half: his hand to us to keep silence, stepped to the door and opened it. The boy handed in a despatch. The Professor closed the door again, and, after looking at the direction, opened it and read aloud.
en_results: his hand to enjoin silence, went to the door, and by a slight motion, directed the boy to enter. The boy handed in a despatch, which the Professor took, and then motioned him to withdraw. As he closed
en_results_raw: his hand to enjoin silence, went to the door, and by a slight motion, directed the boy to enter. The boy handed in a despatch, which the Professor took, and then motioned him to withdraw. As he closed the door, and whilst his back was still turned to us, we heard a low, mirthless laugh, very distinct, but with a peculiar, almost imperceptible tremble in it. Then, as he turned round, his eyes gleaming with amusment, he said, "It is from Lord Godalming, and it is in answer to my telegram of this morning. He has seen the death certificate of the late Mrs. Westenra, and is coming up to town by the next train, and will be with us between five and six this evening." As he spoke, he handed me the telegram, and I read it over his shoulder. It was in the usual formal style of such documents, but the words seemed to dance upon the paper, and the very letters appeared to have a life of their own, as I read them. "Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, at six in the morning. The cause of death was heart disease. The funeral took place on Saturday. I have seen the certificate. Coming up by the five o'clock train. Godalming." As I finished reading, Van Helsing's eyes never left mine, and I could see the unspoken question in them, "What is it that you are thinking of?"

en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....
en_results: even more intense. And yet, I am filled with a sense of foreboding, a feeling that we are running out of time. en_results_raw: room grew darker, I felt a sense of peace settle over me, a sense of being at rest, which I had not known for years. The fire crackled and spat, and Mina stirred in her sleep, but I sat still, lost in thought, and the shadows danced upon the walls, like specters of the past, come to haunt me once more. And yet, even they seemed to have lost their power to harm, and I felt a sense of detachment, as if I were looking on at the scene from afar, and not as one who was a part of it. The clock struck the hour, and I rose, and went to the window, and looked out into the night, and felt the cool breeze upon my face, and the stars shone bright above, and I felt a sense of freedom, a sense of release, which I had not known for years.

I was so taken up with my occupation that I did not hear them steal out of the room, and it was not until I heard the door shut that I knew they had gone. I immediately rose and followed them, but they were nowhere to be seen. I called out, but there was no answer. I was now getting anxious, and I began to fear that some accident had happened to them. I ran to the door and called out again, but still there was no answer. I was now in a state of great alarm, and I did not know what to do. I ran back to the room and got a candle, and then I went out into the passage and called out again, but still there was no answer. I was now in a state of great distress, and I did not know what to do. I ran back to the room and sat down on the bed, and I remained there for some time, not knowing what to do. At last I heard a noise, and I immediately ran out into the passage, and I saw them coming towards me. They told me that they had been out for a walk, and that they had got lost in the passage. I was very much relieved to see them safe, and I was glad that my fears had been groundless. I took them back to the room, and we sat down and talked for some time. We were all very tired, and we soon went to bed.

en_first_half: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.” He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us.
en_second_half: The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!—
en_results: I am getting anxious, as the Professor seems to be in a hurry, and I fear that we may be running out of time. I have been trying to recall any details of my past, but my mind remains a complete blank. The Professor has been trying to reassure me, but I can sense a hint of desperation in his voice. As I look out of the window, I see the rolling hills and dense forests of Transylvania stretching out before us, and I wonder what dangers lie ahead. The Professor has told me that we will be stopping at a village along the way, where we will gather supplies and information, but I fear that we may be walking into a trap. I can feel a sense of foreboding settling over me, and I fear that our journey may be more perilous than I had ever imagined. The Professor has just returned, and is now busy checking the carriage and horses, his face set in a determined expression. I can sense that we are on the brink of something momentous, and I fear that our lives may never be the same again.

es_first_half: 31 de octubre. Llegamos a Veresti por la tarde. El profesor me dice que esta mañana, al amanecer, a duras penas pudo hipnotizarme, y que todo lo que pude decir fue: "oscuro y tranquilo". Ahora está fuera, comprando una calesa y caballos; dice que más tarde tratará de comprar más caballos, de manera que podamos cambiarlos en el camino. Nos quedan todavía ciento diez kilómetros
es_second_half: por recorrer. El paisaje es precioso y muy interesante; si nos encontráramos en diferentes circunstancias, ¡qué encantador resultaría contemplar todo esto! Si Jonathan y yo viajáramos solos por estas tierras, ¡qué placer sería! Podríamos detenernos, veríamos a la gente, aprenderíamos algo sobre ella y llenaríamos nuestras mentes con todo lo pintoresco y el colorido del campo salvaje y hermoso y las personas tan singulares. Pero, ¡ay…!
es_results: para llegar a la frontera. El profesor me dice que, según sus cálculos, deberíamos de poder llegar a la frontera en tres días. en_first_half: Later.—Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers
en_second_half: to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of our being cold.
en_results: to her to add some bottles of the old wine, and she has clapped a small flask of spirits under the straw in the bottom of the carriage. The Professor has also given her some money, and she is to get us some more horses, so that we may
en_results_raw: to her to add some bottles of the old wine, and she has clapped a small flask of spirits under the straw in the bottom of the carriage. The Professor has also given her some money, and she is to get us some more horses, so that we may have some relays, and not have to drive the poor brute we have so far too hard. I can see that he is in a state of great anxiety about something, but I do not know what it is. He keeps looking at his watch, and at the clock, and at the horses, and then at us, as if he is afraid that we shall not get away in time. I have tried to ask him what is the matter, but he will not say. He only says that we must hurry, and that we must not stop until we get to our destination. I am beginning to get a little frightened, for I do not know what is going to happen, and I am afraid that something dreadful is going to occur. I only hope that we shall get away safely, and that nothing shall happen to us on the journey. I shall be glad when we are once more in the quiet of the night, and can talk over what has happened, and try to make out what it all means.

La escena era de una belleza salvaje, con el sol poniente detrás de las montañas, y el castillo alzándose en la distancia, como un fantasma gris. Pero, a pesar de la belleza del paisaje, no podía sacudir de mí la sensación de que algo terrible estaba a punto de suceder, algo que cambiaría nuestras vidas para siempre.
